title: 105_hr1402
content: The Act may be cited as the "Commission on Probabilistic Methods Act". The Congress recognizes the wide applicability of probabilistic methods in improving process efficiency and reducing overdesign in government programs. Integration of these methods in business practices has saved billions for companies, but Federal use lags behind industry. Probabilistic methods offer better understanding of safety and environmental risks, leading to more business-friendly outcomes. Probabilistic methods, if integrated into federally funded design efforts, could enhance understanding of product specifications, reduce overdesign, and lower associated costs. Probabilistic methods, if integrated into federally funded design efforts, could lead to a better understanding of product specifications, reduce overdesign, and lower associated costs in transportation systems. The integration of probabilistic methods in federally funded design efforts could improve the reliability and cost-effectiveness of transportation systems, benefiting various federal agencies. The Administrator of the Research and Special Programs Administration of the Department of Transportation will establish the Commission on Probabilistic Methods to improve the reliability and cost-effectiveness of transportation systems. The Commission on Probabilistic Methods will identify how these methods can benefit the Department of Transportation, assess their potential for maximizing ROI and enhancing public safety, evaluate the technology, recommend practical techniques, and create models for quantifying uncertainties in major transportation programs. The Commission on Probabilistic Methods aims to evaluate technology, recommend practical techniques, establish models for quantifying uncertainties in transportation programs, identify key technology areas for development, recommend implementation guidelines, and set reliability levels for public safety and industry. The Commission on Probabilistic Methods aims to evaluate technology, recommend practical techniques, establish models for quantifying uncertainties in transportation programs, identify key technology areas for development, recommend implementation guidelines, and set reliability levels for public safety and industry. Recommendations include guidelines for safety tests, creating required databases, expediting technology transfer, and ensuring appropriate use of probabilistic methods in decision-making involving funds. The Commission on Probabilistic Methods recommends guidelines for safety tests, creating databases, expediting technology transfer, identifying barriers to effective use of probabilistic methods, and making recommendations for their use in Department of Transportation programs. The Commission on Probabilistic Methods, under the Department of Transportation, identifies legal and cultural barriers to effective use of probabilistic methods, makes recommendations for their use in programs, institutionalizes values, and recommends pilot projects for evaluation of technology. SEC. 5. MEMBERSHIP. The Commission shall consist of 19 members, including a chairperson from an engineering society with experience in probabilistic methods, representatives from higher education, government, industry, labor, environmental community, public interest, and a representative from the Department of Defense appointed by the Secretary of Defense. The Commission consists of 19 members appointed by the Administrator, including representatives from government, industry, labor, environmental community, public interest, and specific departments such as Defense, Commerce, and National Institutes of Health. The Commission consists of 19 members appointed by the Administrator, including representatives from government, industry, labor, environmental community, public interest, Defense, Commerce, and National Institutes of Health. Members serve for life without pay, vacancies filled as per original appointment. The Commission consists of 19 members appointed for life by the Administrator. Vacancies are filled in the same manner as the original appointment. Members serve without pay but receive travel expenses. A quorum is constituted by 10 members, and the initial meeting of the Commission is required. The Commission consists of 19 members appointed for life by the Administrator. Members serve without pay but receive travel expenses. A quorum is constituted by 10 members, and the initial meeting of the Commission is required within 180 days after the enactment of the Act. Within 6 months of the initial meeting, the Commission must provide a written agenda for its activities to the Administrator. SEC. 6. ADMINISTRATIVE SUPPORT. The Commission consists of 19 members appointed for life by the Administrator, serving without pay but receiving travel expenses. A quorum is constituted by 10 members, with the initial meeting required within 180 days of the Act's enactment. Within 6 months of the initial meeting, the Commission must provide a written agenda for its activities to the Administrator. The Department of Transportation will support the Commission administratively. The Commission can hire experts and consultants as needed. It can obtain official data from US departments or agencies and use the US mails for communication. The Commission can obtain official data directly from US departments or agencies and use the US mails for communication. The Commission will provide an interim report to the Administrator within 2 years of its initial meeting and a final report within 36 months. The final report will include findings, conclusions, and recommendations. The Commission will terminate after submitting the final report. SEC. 8. TERMINATION. The Commission will terminate 10 days after submitting its final report. Section 14(a)(2)(B) of the Federal Advisory Committee Act will not apply to the Commission. SEC. 9. BUDGET ACT COMPLIANCE. Any spending authority authorized by this Act will be effective only as provided in appropriation Acts.
